thread.title: Auburn drive-by victims remembered at vigil
thread.title_full: Auburn drive-by victims remembered at vigil | www.kirotv.com

author: kirotv.com
title: Auburn drive-by victims remembered at vigil
text:
Auburn police arrested the person, they believe, pulled the trigger killing a father and his teenage son at a bus stop Tuesday afternoon.
The 19-year-old victim who was killed in front of his father on Tuesday in Auburn was a father himself.
David Mireles lost his cousin and uncle in the apparent drive-by shooting.
Tonight, he and a group of friends gathered at the scene of the shooting to honor both men.
Mireles said he is glad the suspect was caught, but the damage is done.
A group gathered near the intersection of B Street SE and 17th Street SE in Auburn with flowers, candles and some cans and bottles of beer.
Angel Mireles, 19, and his father, Mark Rivera, 40, were gunned down Tuesday evening while waiting for a ride by a bus stop.
Police say the gunman pulled up and fired shots at Angel Mireles first.
"We were all oldest and he's our littlest cousin and I can't believe our little cousin is gone now, man," Mireles said.
On Wednesday, police found the suspect's stolen car with blood on it in Tacoma.
They also found the suspect in an Auburn home, but would not elaborate on what led them to the house or the man they arrested, only saying their investigation led them to him.
Meanwhile, Mark Rivera, 40, died Wednesday afternoon at Harborview Medical Center.
"I thought he was going to make it," said Mireles of his uncle.
Mireles admits he wanted to hunt down his family's killer, but something stopped him:
"I'm going to be a father soon. What if my child won't remember me because I went out there for revenge and I die," he said to friends at the vigil.
Now he thinks of the one-year-old boy who will never know his father, Angel.
â€œIt's so hard for my nephew that he's not going to have a daddy in his life now, man," Mireles said.
Auburn police say a woman, possibly the passenger in the car, was also taken into custody for questioning. She could face charges.
As for a motive, police say they do not have one.
When asked if drugs or gangs had anything to do with the shooting, a police department spokesperson said they do not know at this time.
